awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Migration Towards Terascale Flexible-Grid Optical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Fiber optic networks are deployed worldwide in telecom backbone networks to carry the huge and exponentially growing amount of Internet traffic.   However, this traffic growth is straining the capacity of fiber optic networks, which has led researchers to explore new ways of using the bandwidth available in them.  Traditionally, a fiber's spectrum is divided into a fixed grid of equally-spaced optical channels.  To squeeze more out of the available spectrum, this conventional fixed grid is evolving towards a flexible grid, where individual channels can be placed anywhere in the spectrum, and sized to match the traffic they carry.  This research will investigate novel migration strategies from fixed-grid towards next-generation flexible-grid fiber networks, and strategies for maximizing the traffic a network can carry.  This will enable high network efficiency, thus lowering the cost of the communications networks that underlie the Internet.  

Flex-grid technology holds enormous potential, but also brings with it significant complexity.  This project tackles the two main issues associated with incorporating flex-grid technology into communications networks.  First, it will investigate potential fixed-to-flex grid migration strategies, taking into account the complexities of device characteristics, detailed node architectures and physical (signal) impairments in network optimization studies. The project will systematically address possible upgrade paths, including which node(s) should be upgraded first, whether and where flex-grid 'islands' should be created within networks, and how many nodes should be upgraded for current network state.  The project will use a 24-node nationwide network with aggregate terabit-per-second traffic demand to explore the relative advantages and disadvantages of each approach. The project's second major thrust is to tackle the problem of traffic grooming in such networks.  While traditional traffic grooming is essentially a combined routing and (fixed-size) bin-packing problem, the focus here is on novel strategies to efficiently aggregate traffic as container (bin) sizes vary in time.

por.por_cntn:
Backbone optical networks are deployed worldwide to carry Internet traffic over high-speed optical paths. With traffic growing at 30-40% annually, optical spectrum is becoming scarce, and operators must embrace network architectures which support channels operating at terabit-per-second (Tbps) speeds. The conventional fixed grid (where an optical fiber's spectrum is divided using Wavelength-Division Multiplexing (WDM) into equally-spaced optical channels supporting fixed line rates) is evolving towards a flexible grid with introduction of higher-bit-rate transponders capable of tuning their data rate (i.e., elastic rate). This allows efficient spectrum utilization by assigning more granular frequency slots to serve diverse traffic demands with appropriate spectral resources.

 

Intrinsic Merit: This project has created new knowledge and understanding on migration strategies from fixed grid to flexible grid in next-generation optical networks, and the co-existence and interoperability of fixed-grid and flex-grid technologies (mixed-grid scenario). Today's state-of-the-art lacks efficient management of such mixed-grid networks. This project has investigated how to solve the dynamic Routing and Spectrum Allocation (RSA) problem with optimum spectrum efficiency for the mixed-grid, adapting the modulation formats of transmitted optical signals for cost and performance efficiency. Optimum migration strategies from fixed to flex grid have been developed to maximize cost benefit and minimize service interruption during the migration process. Also, other recent migration trends have been explored such as migration from C to C+L bands, inter/intra-DC elastic optical networks (EONs), exploiting virtual network functions (VNFs), Machine-Learning (ML)-driven solutions, etc.

 

Broader Impacts: Developing optimum strategies for gradual migration from fixed grid to flexible grid in next-generation optical networks can have a profound effect on society as we try to manage increasing traffic demands and exhaustion of spectral resources. This NSF project has shown how to leverage interoperability of fixed-grid and flex-grid technologies (mixed-grid scenario) and achieve optimum spectrum efficiency through migration and intelligent routing and spectrum allocation.

This project has had a significant impact on development of human resources. Dr.(Ms) Tanjila Ahmed, Dr. Sabidur Rahman, Dr.(Ms) Lin Wang, and Dr.(Ms) Sifat Ferdousi have worked on design and analysis of methods to solve practical problems in optical networks. Their research focused on various aspects of optical network migration such as efficient routing and spectrum allocation for fixed- and flex-grid networks and from C to C+L bands, among others. Dr. Lin Wang, upon graduation from UC Davis, is now working at Facebook; and Dr. Sabidur Rahman is Assistant Professor at Sonoma State University. Several international collaborators were attracted to our project: from Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology (IIIT) Delhi, India; British Telecom, UK; Federal University of Bahia, Brazil; and Politecnico di Torino, Italy.

Our research has been published in leading journals and conferences. Our work on routing and spectrum allocation (RSA) in mixed-grid networks and dynamic Optical Signal-to-Noise Ratio (OSNR) allocation for resource crunch resulted in two papers in IEEE ANTS'18 conference. Extending RSA to Route, Spectrum, and Modulation format Assignment (RSMA) led to a publication in IEEE/OSA Journal of Optical Communications and Networking (JOCN), 2020.  A very-early paper on migrating gradually from current fixed-grid to flex-grid was published by us in IEEE Communications Magazine (Feb.2015). A paper on provisioning short-term traffic fluctuations in flex-grid optical networks was published in IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking (TON), 2019. A study on revenue maximization with adaptive modulation in flexible optical networks is submitted to TON.

We also investigated how emerging applications/trends are going to change migration strategies, e.g.: i) from C to C+L bands (JOCN'2020 and OFC'21); ii) migration towards virtual network functions (VNFs) to support service chains (IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management, 2020); iii) migration to virtualized controllers for multi-domain optical networks (ACP'18 and ONDM'19 conferences, and Invited Paper in Photonic Network Communications (PNET), 2020); iv) deferred protection while migrating towards inter-DC EONs (ONDM'2020); v) use of ML for QoT estimation in EONs (IEEE INFOCOM'19, JOCN'2020, and submitted to TON); vi) cost-efficient VNF placement and scheduling in public cloud networks (IEEE Transactions on Communications (TCOM), 2020); vii) migration towards virtualized cloud-fog radio access network (JOCN'2019); viii) migration towards multi-core fibers and crosstalk-aware resource allocation (TCOM'2019); ix) migration towards few-mode transmission and efficient spectrum usage (IEEE/OSA Journal of Lightwave Technology (JLT), 2019); x) migration towards Optical Time-Switching System (OTSS)-enabled flex-grid intra-DC networks (PNET'2021); xi) virtual-machine placement and workload assignment in cooperative edge-cloud computing (IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing, 2021); and xii) migration towards packet-switched optical DC networks (PNET'2021). 

The PI and Co-PI Co-Edited the Springer Handbook on Optical Networks (September 2020). The PI Co-Edits Springer's Optical Networks Book Series, publishing optical-networking books under his supervision. PI Mukherjee Co-Guest-Edited the May 2012 Centennial Issue (vol.100) of Proceedings of the IEEE on "The Evolution of Optical Networking". Co-PI Tornatore Co-Guest-Edited the "Latest Advances in Optical Networks for 5G Communications and Beyond" issue for IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications, 2021. Thus, the role of this NSF project has been excellent.
